At 22:32 12/03/2006, you wrote:
>Ian Badcoe wrote:
>
> >Hi,
> >       I am developing a SLEAT TicTacToe screen saver, to use the space
> >cycles of the various machines I have available.
> >
> >       I was wondering whether anybody else would be interested in 
> running it for me?
> >
> >
>Yeh sure. It might be easier if there was a plain EXE version since I
>tend to use Remote Connection to my workhorse PC and then
>logoff/disconnect leaving processes running with no display - and hence
>no screensaver. Also it has other (low CPU) jobs to do, so keeping the
>CPU priority low would be nice.

I usually set it to, err, whatever cryptic phrase MS use for a 
priority in stead of a nice simple number that anybody would 
understand, err, oh yes, "THREAD_PRIORITY_BELOW_NORMAL", would that 
do you?  Can windows be in a state where there is no display?  I mean 
it's not like *nix where there needn't be a graphical front-end at all...

Anyway, I'm going to do an alternative exe that sits in the system 
tray (because my machine at work has _two_ CPU's (whooo!) and a 
single-thread app can use at most 1 of them, so I was going to stick 
the exe in the system tray all the time (with an option to 
right-click on it and pause it for if I need both CPUs) and the 
screen-saver to come in when the machine is completely not-in-use and 
use the other CPU...

But you might have to wait a little longer for that, say until after 
the weekend...

> >       It's not as fully automatic as Seti@Home, in that you will need to
> >mail the results back to me (which will typically zip down to 
> about 1/2 a meg).
>BTW 7-zip (www.7-zip.org) is a nice tool for zipping up files. I've seen
>it compress files to a quarter the size of an equivalent zip at max
>compression, so it might help alleviate the load on your mailbox.

Yes I have that, although I tend to avoid the heavier compression 
methods for fear of incompatibility, but if we both use 7-zip 
obviously we'll be OK,

Ian

In 15 minutes everybody will be in the future.
